awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Role of the Low-Level Jet in Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Drought over the Southern Great Plains
awd_abstract_narration:
The role of local land conditions in drought evolution, as a potential agent of local climate self-regulation is poorly understood, as are the multi-scale land-atmosphere interactions involved. This project will improve understanding of drought evolution and its predictability in the southern Great Plains through synergistic efforts in analyzing impacts of low-level jets on local land-atmosphere couplings over the Great Plains and the regulatory role of the ocean on the Great Plains low-level jet. Specifically, this project will examine how local drought conditions may, under different conditions of weather sequencing and large-scale climate variability, serve to trigger rainfall and initiate an eventual recovery from drought. The primary tools for this project include observational data analyses (tabular and composite analyses, probabilistic event characterization, and synoptic and mesoscale analyses of droughts and low-level jet variability) and numerical modeling.

The project will yield new knowledge and insights into mechanisms of drought predictability, which can in-turn be used to guide process-level refinement of weather-, seasonal forecast-, and climate models. For the semi-arid southern Great Plains, a pillar of the nation's food and energy security, it is critical that drought and its mechanisms be better understood, particularly in the context of climate variability and change. Every sector of the economy, in addition to public safety and health, benefits from improved forecast skill. Other important project outcomes include the validation of current cloud-resolving models and the training of one graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher in the areas of synoptic-scale and mesoscale meteorology, and coupled modeling.

por.por_cntn:
Great Plains low-level jets (LLJs) are responsible for 30-50% of May-September precipitation in the Great Plains and more than 30% of US total wind energy production. The considerable societal impacts of LLJs, which span agriculture, severe weather, and wind energy, have long motivated investigations into their dynamics and predictability. The objective of this project was to improve understanding of LLJs in the context of land surface processes, namely, regional soil moisture gradients.

The first major accomplishment of this project was the development of a novel, objective, automatable LLJ classification methodology capable of distinguishing between LLJs that are strongly coupled to an upper-level synoptic trough from LLJs that are relatively uncoupled from synoptic flow, and thus more sensitive to surface soil moisture gradients. In the project's initial phase, we applied this methodology to output from ECMWF's Coupled Reanalysis of the Twentieth Century for the period from 1901-2010. We performed a climatological comparison of coupled and uncoupled LLJs, and found that coupled LLJs tend to be longer-lived with greater maximum wind speeds and associated precipitation. These findings underscore the importance of distinguishing between LLJ types in seasonal forecasts and climate projections. Subsequently,  we investigated the seasonality of LLJ types. We found that coupled LLJs were most frequent in May and September, whereas uncoupled LLJs were most frequent during June-August. Decreased uncoupled LLJ frequency explains a significant long-term, ongoing decreasing trend in the available wind energy resource. Similarly, up to 44% of recent declines in warm-season precipitation in the northern and central Plains is attributable to changes in LLJ frequency. Prior to the advent of our automated LLJ classification methodology, such LLJ-type studies were precluded by the need for painstaking expert weather map diagnosis.

The second major accomplishment of this project was a quantification of LLJ sensitivity to regional soil moisture gradients. First, using idealized regional climate model simulation in which anomalously wet and dry soil conditions were prescribed across the U.S., the team demonstrated a connection between soil moisture and LLJ wind speeds and LLJ northward advancement. Then, building upon this finding, the team carried out model simulations for 75 real LLJ cases--both with- and without satellite soil moisture data assimilation. The results reveal for the first time the added-value of soil moisture data assimilation for short-term LLJ forecasts. The location of the LLJ exit region, where the most extreme precipitation tends to fall, was found to be particularly sensitive to soil moisture gradients. Collectively, the team's findings will help justify investments to include satellite soil moisture data assimilation in the nation's operational weather forecast systems.

The final accomplishment of the project relates to the potential predictability of LLJs at 1-4 week lead times. Based on analysis of the new 1901-2010 LLJ classification dataset, along with additional output fields from  ECMWF's Coupled Reanalysis of the Twentieth Century, the team identified a significant correlation between LLJ type and the magnitude of a circumglobal teleconnection that connects western Asia and U.S. climate. The existence of this correlation indicates substantial 1-2 month lead time predictability of LLJ type, and along with it, associated Great Plains hydroclimate. This source of LLJ predictability was previously overlooked because it only presents itself when the LLJs are separated by upper-level coupling strength.

Funding from this project supported a tenured professor of atmospheric science (Co-PI Bosart), a pre-tenured professor of hydrology (PI Ferguson), two postdoctoral researchers (Burrows and Agrawal), and two graduate students (Campbell and Gyawali). In total, the research team published nine peer-reviewed journal articles and one dataset, the Great Plains Low-Level Jet Occurrence and Upper-Level Coupling CERA-20C dataset, which is available for download from the Research Data Archive at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (https://doi.org/10.5065/KDB5-9X72). The team gave more than 20 project-related research presentations at annual meetings of the American Meteorological Society, American Geophysical Union, and European Geosciences Union. Additionally, at least two research presentations were given per year at meetings of the University at Albany Climate Group. The team's findings set the groundwork for future improvements in forecasting societally-relevant LLJs and their associated severe weather at 1-30 day lead times. A partially-supported study that quantified the energy production and water conservation benefits of floating solar on U.S. reservoirs contributed to a first-of-its-kind municipality-owned and operated floating solar project in Cohoes, NY.
